description: On Feb 24 2020 the Croatian Ministry of Health raised the alert level due to the risk of coronavirus.

On Mar 5 2020 the Croatian Minister of Health has adopted the decision to declare the risk of an epidemic of the infectious disease Covid 19. It is an administrative measure that does not indicate the degree of threat but allows the Minister to mobilize all resources in the healthcare system, to relocate infectious diseases doctors and other healthcare professionals and equipment as needed, thus enabling better management of the healthcare system. 
The decision of declaration of epidemic diseases Covide-19 in the whole Republic of Croatia was implemented on Mar 11 2020. UPDATE: The original alert was raised to a declaration of epidemic diseases on Mar 5 and implemented on Mar 11.

On Feb 24 2020 the Croatian Ministry of Health raised the alert level due to the risk of coronavirus.

On March 11, the Government of Croatia declared the national state of emergency, and therefore, the previous policy ended. UPDATE: This policy was ended with the national state of emergency on March 5.

On Feb 24 the Crisis Headquarters of the Croatian Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including increased surveillance of border crossings to Italy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 30 the Republic of Croatia temporarily closes six permanent border crossings (Umag, Poreč, Rovinj, Mali Lošinj, Korčula and Ubli) and postpones the opening of eleven seasonal crossings (Umag-ACI Marina, Novigrad, Sali, Božava, Primošten, Komiža, Hvar, Vis, Stari Grad on the island of Hvar, Vela Luka and Cavtat) for international passenger traffic in maritime transport. UPDATE: Croatia updates its closure of border crossings.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On Mar 31 The Croatian Ministry of the Interior said the border regime would be relaxed allowing Croatian and Hungarian citizens living or working within 30 km of the border to cross the border every day or when necessary. The relaxed sanitary measures refer only to those who have a justified reason to cross the border in order to perform work that is considered economically important as well as to persons who own farms in the other country. UPDATE: Croatia relaxes its border with Hungary

description: On Mar 31 the Croatian Science Foundation with financing from the Ministry of Science and Education has invited scientists to apply for 14 million kuna in grants for research related to the coronavirus. The research is not limited to medicine and public health, but also the social aspects of the pandemic and its effects on the education system. The researchers have 18 months to complete their projects.

description: On Mar 4 2020 the Croatian Institute for Public Health issued new recommendations regarding the disinfection of ambulance vehicles and sanitary vehicles: buses, trains, ships and aircraft as well as recommendations for carrying out transport activities.

description: On May 4th, both hair and beauty salons will be opening up with hygiene regulations including: mandatory posting of information on hygiene, social distancing (1.5 meters) between clients and staff (Plexiglass barrier recommended for regular cleaning and disinfection), disinfectants (must be available in waiting rooms/entrance area, payment desk, and work area). It is recommended that towels and gowns are replaced by disposable towels and gowns and that both staff and clients wear gloves and face masks.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Apr 1 the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 leaving one's place of residence will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On Apr 1 the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 moving between different administrative units of the country, will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.

On April 19, National Civil Protection Headquarters declared that from April 20 e-passes for movement between the area of the City of Zagreb and Zagreb County have been abolished. Passes for Vukovar-Srijem County, Osijek-Baranja County, Varaždin County, Karlovac County, Brod-Posavina County, Požega County, Slavonia County and Split-Dalmatia County are also being abolished, with the exception of the islands, while the Lika-Senj County Civil Protection Headquarters will decide on Monday. UPDATE: The e-passes were cancelled for the big part of the territory on April 19, and therefore I am ending this policy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 9th, 2020, the Croatian National Civil Protection Headquarters declared that residents of Brač cannot leave the island without e-passes, for a period of 14 days.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On Dec 18 the Croatian Civil Protection Headquarters declared that as of December 23 moving between different administrative units of the country, will be possible only with an e-pass. This policy lasted until December 29, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23. 

Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23. 

Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.

Based on the proposals received from the county headquarters, the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia issued a Decision on the abolition of the prohibition of leaving the place of residence and permanent residence for several counties:
 
For the area of the City of Zagreb and Zagreb County
Vukovar-Srijem County
Brod-Posavina County
Osijek-Baranja County
Požega-Slavonia County
Virovitica-Podravina County
Bjelovar-Bilogora County
Koprivnica-Križevci County
Međimurje County
Karlovac County
Primorje-Gorski Kotar County
Zadar County
Šibenik-Knin County
Split-Dalmatia County UPDATE: The general lockdown for whole country was lifted on April 20, allowing free movement of people in many parts of the country.

description: On April 14, the Croatian Ministry of Health introduced Andrija - the first digital coronavirus assistant in Croatia. The app helps people recognize symptoms of coronavirus infection (self-assessment of their own health status), connects people to competent institutions, allows people to report relevant information from their household, and helps nursing home employees understand health protocols.

description:
On Feb 23 the Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travelers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
On Feb 24th, Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travellers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy. For all persons who have been in close contact with a patient, self-isolation is foreseen in their own home with daily contact with the epidemiologist or organized quarantine if there are no conditions for self-isolation.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 12 the Croatian Interior Minister Davor Božinović announced Croatia added more countries to a list of those whose nationals will have to be quarantined if they want to enter the country. These measures apply to citizens of Germany, France, Switzerland, Spain, Austria, the UK, the Netherlands, and Sweden. They will be required to undergo strict self-quarantine measures. UPDATE: Croatia added more countries to a list of those whose nationals will have to be quarantined if they want to enter the country.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Mar 15 Croatia has expanded the list of countries from which travelers will have to self-isolate for 14 days on arrival in Croatia, the Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs said on Sunday, stressing that the measure applies to Croatians and foreign nationals alike. UPDATE: Croatia has expanded the list of countries and the measure applies to Croatians and foreign nationals alike

Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors.

description:
On April 17, Croatian Parliament, pursuant to Article 89 of the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia, enacted decision on the promulgation of the law on amendments to the law on protection of the population from infectious diseases. 

With new amendments, for the people who are suspected of suffering from COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus or healthy persons who have been in contact with persons suffering from the disease, or come from the area of the affected COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, health professionals may determine the isolation in their own home, or in another suitable space - a self-isolation, if appropriate conditions are met (Art. 8). 

Furthermore, for each violation of the provisions of this Act, the sanitary inspector of the State Inspectorate may, on the spot, charge a fine in the amount of HRK 5,000.00 (660 euros). (Art. 17).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 17, Croatian Parliament, pursuant to Article 89 of the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia, enacted decision on the promulgation of the law on amendments to the law on protection of the population from infectious diseases. 

With new amendments, for the people who are suspected of suffering from COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus or healthy persons who have been in contact with persons suffering from the disease, or come from the area of the affected COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, health professionals may determine the isolation in their own home, or in another suitable space - a self-isolation, if appropriate conditions are met (Art. 8). 

Furthermore, for each violation of the provisions of this Act, the sanitary inspector of the State Inspectorate may, on the spot, charge a fine in the amount of HRK 5,000.00 (660 euros). (Art. 17).
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Mar 14 Istria County his shuttering all hospitality businesses for the next month in a move to try and curb the spread of the coronavirus. All cafes and restaurants will be closed until April 14. Food delivery services and soup kitchens are exempt but are under strict cautionary measures, said Damir Kozlovac, the head of county civil defense services.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down

logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers.

description:

description: 9 March 2020 the Croatian National headquarters for coronavirus introduced new measures to prevent spreading of virus: It is recommended to postpone all public events with more than 1000 people. If organizers however decide to organize such events, they must ensure high hygienic standards.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On Mar 12 the Croatian government recommended postponement or limitation of gatherings with more than 100 people, as well as sports events without spectators. UPDATE: The original recommendation of limiting events to 1000 people was lowered to 100 people.
On March 19 Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days.
On March 19, Croatian government cancelled religious services (all public events, gatherings, and meetings of more than 5 persons in one place).
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description: On March 19, Croatian government cancelled religious services (all public events, gatherings, and meetings of more than 5 persons in one place). The policy ended on May 2, allowing religious services to resume. UPDATE: Originally, on March 19, religious services were cancelled. However, the policy ended on May 2, since religious services were able to resume.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
9 March 2020 the Croatian National headquarters for coronavirus introduced new measures to prevent spreading of virus: It is recommended to postpone all public events with more than 1000 people. If organizers however decide to organize such events, they must ensure high hygienic standards. On Mar 12 the Croatian government recommended postponement or limitation of gatherings with more than 100 people, as well as sports events without spectators. Effective March 19, all sports competitions will be closed. 
 UPDATE: Originally, in Croatia, sports competitions that included more than 100 people were recommended to be suspended. However, effective March 19, all sports competitions will be closed.
On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals. This measured was extended until May 4 with the following precautionary measures: no music, flowers or candles, and obituaries may not contain information on the time and place of the funeral UPDATE: The original restriction (March 21) of funerals being limited to immediate family members and religious representatives was extended to May 4.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19 Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days. The policy was updated on beginning May 11, where public gatherings of up to 10 people were allowed outdoors. UPDATE: Originally, on March 19, the Croatian government had a set a ban on a gathering of more than 5 people but beginning May 11, public gatherings of up to 10 people were allowed outdoors.

On March 3 the Croatian Institute of Public Health has issued recommendations for the preservation of health of persons over 60 years of age and those suffering from chronic diseases who should avoid visits and entry into crowded public areas and routine check-ups and visits to general practitioners and hospitals should be skipped unless there is a need for urgent health care services.
On March 16, the Ministry of Health in Croatia announced their recommendation for people suffering respiratory infection symptoms to wear a mask.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 17 the Croatian national civil defense headquarters has once again called to limit the movement of the elderly so that they do not leave their residences unless absolutely necessary. UPDATE: Elderly people should not only avoid mass gatherings but limit going outdoors in general.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Croatia on March 19, the government implemented a strict measurement of social distancing to avoid close personal contact at a distance of at least two (2) meters indoors and one (1) meter outdoors for 30 days.

On Mar 21 the Croatia national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by rail, bus and tram, for the next 30 days, and the decision goes into force on Sunday, March 22.
All railway and bus stations will be closed. Travel to islands will be possible only for people who live on islands.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 14, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued recommendations of social distancing for visitors at  beaches as well as freshwater and sea swimming areas. These recommendations include  a maximum number of 15 people per one hundred square meters on the beaches and maintaining 1.5 m physical distance between individuals in the water.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued a recommendation for drivers of public transportation (buses and trams) to wear masks. This policy was updated on June 25 which required both drivers and passengers in public transportation to wear masks. UPDATE: Originally on April 24, the Croatian Institute of Public health recommended drivers of public transportation to wear masks. However, this policy was updated on June 25, making it mandatory for both passengers and drivers to wear a mask.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
